e||"object"!=typeof e)return!1;var t=document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0],n=function(e,n){var o=document.createElement("style");o.type="text/css","undefined"!=typeof e.hideKey&&n(e.hideKey+"{visibility:visible}")};if("undefined"!=typeof e.hideKey&&n(e.hideKey+"{visibility:hidden}"),"undefined"!=typeof e.fontKey&&"undefined"!=typeof e.staticHost&&"undefined"!=typeof e.version&&"undefined"!=typeof e.woff2Version){var i=e.fontKey,a=e.version,f=e.woff2Version,r=e.staticHost,d="woff",s=!1;f&&(s=function(e){if(!("FontFace"in e))return!1;var t=new e.FontFace("t",\'url( "data:application/font-woff2," ) format( "woff2" )\',{});try{var n=t.load();"undefined"!=typeof n.then&&n.then(function(){},function(){})}catch(o){return!1}return"loading"==t.status}(window)),s?d="woff2":navigator.userAgent.indexOf("Android")>-1&&(d="ttf");var c="vanFont-"+i+"-"+d,u=c+".json",y=function(){var e=document.createElement("script");e.type="text/javascript",e.async=!0,e.src="//"+r+"/"+a+"/media/fonts/json/"+u,t.appendChild(e)},l=!1,v=!1;try{if(l=localStorage.getItem(c)){var v=JSON.parse(l);v.version!=a&&(localStorage.removeItem(c),v=!1)}}catch(p){console.error("Error when parsing font in vanFontLoader",p)}v&&"undefined"!=typeof v.value?(n(v.value,i),o()):y()}this.store=function(e){e.version=a;var t=JSON.stringify(e);localStorage.setItem(c,t),n(e.value),o()}}; try {\nvar OpenSans_vanFontLoader = new vanFontLoader({fontKey: \'OpenSans\', version: 1, woff2Version: true, staticHost: \'vanilla.futurecdn.net/livescience\' });\nvar livescience_vanFontLoader = new vanFontLoader({fontKey: \'livescience\', version: 1, woff2Version: false, staticHost: \'vanilla.futurecdn.net/livescience\' ,hideKey: \'.icon\' });\n} catch(e) {\nconsole.warn(\'Failed to load fonts: \'+ e.message);\n}\n</script>\n<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,initial-scale=1">\n<title>Coronavirus can survive on skin for 9 hours | Live Science</title>\n<meta name="pub_date" content="2020-10-07T11:38:57+00:00">\n<meta name="description" content="The new coronavirus can linger on human skin much longer than flu viruses can, according to a new study from researchers in Japan.">\n<link rel="canonical" href="https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html">\n<style content="post">\n<meta name="parsely-post-id" content="6Ufx72SzvJ3aUkWKWXD5Y">\n<meta name="parsely-pub-date" content="2020-10-07T11:38:57Z">\n<meta name="parsely-title" content="Coronavirus can survive on skin for 9 hours">\n<meta name="parsely-link" content="https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html">\n<meta name="parsely-image-url" Other,Category: News,covid-19,coronavirus,human skin,virus,channel_other,type_news,serversidehawk,videoarticle">\n<meta name="parsely-author" content="Rachael Rettner">\n<script type="application/ld+json">\n{\n"@type": "NewsArticle",\n"name": "Coronavirus can survive on skin for 9 hours",\n"headline": "Coronavirus can survive on skin for 9 hours",\n"articleBody": "The new coronavirus can linger on human skin much longer than flu viruses can, according to a new study from researchers in Japan. SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, remained viable on samples of human skin for about 9 hours, according to the study. In contrast, a strain of the influenza A virus (IAV) remained viable on human skin for about 2 hours. Fortunately, both viruses on skin were rapidly inactivated with hand sanitizer . The findings underscore the importance of washing your\xe2\x80\xa6",\n"datePublished": "2020-10-07T11:38:57Z",\n"image": "https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg",\n"author": data-id="6Ufx72SzvJ3aUkWKWXD5Y">\n<header>\n<nav class="breadcrumb" aria-label="Breadcrumbs">\n<ol>\n<li><a href="https://www.livescience.com/">Home</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://www.livescience.com/news">News</a></li>\n</ol>\n</nav>\n<h1>Coronavirus can survive on skin for 9 hours</h1>\n<div class="byline-social">\n<p class="byline">\nBy\n<span class="no-wrap by-author"><a href="https://www.livescience.com/author/rachael-rettner" rel="author"><span style="white-space: nowrap">Rachael Rettner</span> - <span>Senior Writer</span></a></span>\n<time itemprop="datePublished" class="no-wrap relative-date chunk" datetime="2020-10-07T11:38:57Z">07 October 2020</time>\n</p>\n<p class="strapline"></p>\n<nav class="socialite-widget box less-space " data-contexturl="https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html">\n<ul class="socialite-widget-ul">\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Facebook" href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html" data-platform="facebook" target="_blank" class="facebook socialite" data-action="share" aria-label="Facebook">\n<i class="icon icon-facebook"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Twitter" href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Coronavirus%20can%20survive%20on%20skin%20for%209%20hours&amp;url=https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html" data-platform="twitter" target="_blank" class="twitter socialite" data-action="tweet" aria-label="Twitter">\n<i class="icon icon-twitter"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item mobile-only">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Whatsapp" href="whatsapp://send?text=Coronavirus%20can%20survive%20on%20skin%20for%209%20hourshttps://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html?fwa" data-platform="whatsapp" class="whatsapp socialite" data-action="message" aria-label="WhatsApp">\n<i class="icon icon-whats-app"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Reddit" href="http://www.reddit.com/submit?url=https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html&amp;title=Coronavirus%20can%20survive%20on%20skin%20for%209%20hours" data-platform="reddit" target="_blank" class="reddit socialite" data-action="submit" aria-label="Reddit">\n<i class="icon icon-reddit"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Pinterest" href="http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html&amp;media=https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-1200-80.jpg" data-platform="pinterest" target="_blank" class="pinterest socialite" data-action="pin" aria-label="Pinterest">\n<i class="icon icon-pinterest"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Flipboard" href="https://share.flipboard.com/bookmarklet/popout?title=Coronavirus%20can%20survive%20on%20skin%20for%209%20hours&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.livescience.com%2Fcoronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html" data-platform="flipboard" target="_blank" class="flipboard socialite" data-action="flip" aria-label="Flipboard">\n<i class="icon icon-flipboard"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n<li class="socialite-widget-item">\n<a data-component-tracking-label="Email" href="mailto:?subject=I%20found%20this%20webpage&amp;body=Hi,%20I%20found%20this%20webpage%20and%20thought%20you%20might%20like%20it%20https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-survives-9-hours-on-skin.html" class="email socialite" data-platform="email" aria-label="Email">\n<i class="icon icon-envelope-solid"></i>\n</a>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<div class="num-shares-wrapper"><i class="icon icon-share"></i> <span class="num-shares-label">Shares</span> <span class="num-shares-value"></span></div>\n<a class="xenforo-nav-link" href="#xenforo-comments-3753">\n<i class="icon icon-comment"></i>\n<span class="comments-total">Comments (3)</span>\n</a>\n</nav>\n</div>\n</header>\n<section class="content-wrapper">\n<div class="box">\n<picture><source type="image/webp" alt="Coronavirus particles shown on skin during a handshake." class=" block-image-ads hero-image" onerror="if(this.src &amp;&amp; this.src.indexOf(\'missing-image.svg\') !== -1){return true;};this.parentNode.replaceChild(window.missingImage(),this)" srcset="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-320-80.jpg.webp 320w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-480-80.jpg.webp 480w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-650-80.jpg.webp 650w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-970-80.jpg.webp 970w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-1024-80.jpg.webp 1024w" sizes="(min-width: 1000px) 970px, calc(100vw - 40px)" data-original-mos="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg" data-pin-media="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg"></source><source type="image/jpeg" alt="Coronavirus particles shown on skin during a handshake." class=" block-image-ads hero-image" onerror="if(this.src &amp;&amp; this.src.indexOf(\'missing-image.svg\') !== -1){return true;};this.parentNode.replaceChild(window.missingImage(),this)" srcset="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-320-80.jpg 320w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-480-80.jpg 480w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-650-80.jpg 650w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-970-80.jpg 970w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-1024-80.jpg 1024w" sizes="(min-width: 1000px) 970px, calc(100vw - 40px)" data-original-mos="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg" data-pin-media="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg"></source><img src="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-320-80.jpg" alt="Coronavirus particles shown on skin during a handshake." class=" block-image-ads hero-image" onerror="if(this.src &amp;&amp; this.src.indexOf(\'missing-image.svg\') !== -1){return true;};this.parentNode.replaceChild(window.missingImage(),this)" srcset="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-320-80.jpg 320w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-480-80.jpg 480w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-650-80.jpg 650w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-970-80.jpg 970w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ-1024-80.jpg 1024w" sizes="(min-width: 1000px) 970px, calc(100vw - 40px)" data-original-mos="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg" data-pin-media="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg"></picture>\n<div class="credit">(Image: \xc2\xa9 Shutterstock)</div>\n</div>\n<div itemprop="articleBody" id="article-body" class="text-copy bodyCopy auto">\n<div itemprop="image" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/ImageObject">\n<meta itemprop="url" content="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6ALn9JFVMADYcB9vkxJmwQ.jpg">\n<meta itemprop="height" content="602">\n<meta itemprop="width" content="370">\n</div>\n<p>The new coronavirus can linger on human skin much longer than flu viruses can, according to a new study from researchers in Japan.</p><p>SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, remained viable on samples of human skin for about 9 hours, according to the study. In contrast, a strain of the <a href="https://www.livescience.com/54509-flu-influenza.html"><u>influenza</u></a> A virus (IAV) remained viable on human skin for about 2 hours.</p><aside class="hawk-placeholder" data-render-type="fte" data-skip="dealsy" data-widget-type="seasonal"></aside><p>Fortunately, both viruses on skin were rapidly inactivated with <a href="https://www.livescience.com/hand-sanitizer.html"><u>hand sanitizer</u></a>.</p><p>The findings underscore the importance of washing your hands or using sanitizer to prevent the spread of COVID-19.</p><p>"This study shows that SARS-CoV-2 may have a higher risk of contact transmission [i.e. transmission from direct contact] than IAV because the first is much more stable on human skin [than the latter]" the authors wrote in their paper, which was published online Oct. 3 in the journal <a href="https://academic.oup.com/cid/advance-article/doi/10.1093/cid/ciaa1517/5917611" target="_blank" data-original-href="https://academic.oup.com/cid/advance-article/doi/10.1093/cid/ciaa1517/5917611"><u>Clinical Infectious Diseases</u></a>. "These findings support the hypothesis that proper hand hygiene is important for the prevention of the spread of SARS-CoV-2."</p><p><strong>Related: </strong><a href="https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-myths.html"><u><strong>14 coronavirus myths busted by science</strong></u></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p><div id="futr_botr_T4pPkX58_tfejT8dc_div" class="future__jwplayer"><div id="botr_T4pPkX58_tfejT8dc_div"></div></div><p class="mid__article"></p><h2 id="survival-on-skin">Survival on skin</h2><p>Earlier in the pandemic, researchers in the U.S. analyzed how long SARS-CoV-2 could last on surfaces and found it remained viable on copper surfaces for up to 4 hours, on cardboard for up to 24 hours and on plastic and stainless steel for up to 72 hours, <a href="https://www.livescience.com/how-long-coronavirus-last-surfaces.html"><u>Live Science previously reported</u></a>. However, for ethical reasons, examining how long the virus can last on human skin is more complicated &mdash; you can\'t just put samples of a potentially lethal virus on people\'s hands.</p><p>So for the new study, the researchers, from Kyoto Prefectural University of Medicine in Japan, created a skin model using samples of <a href="https://www.livescience.com/27115-skin-facts-diseases-conditions.html"><u>human skin</u></a> obtained from autopsies. The samples were collected approximately one day after death. The authors note that even 24 hours after death, human skin can still be used for skin grafts, meaning that it retains much of its function for some time after death. Thus, the collected samples could be a suitable model for human skin, the authors argued.</p><div class="fancy-box"><div class="fancy_box-title">Related content</div><div class="fancy_box_body"><p><strong>&mdash;</strong><a href="https://www.livescience.com/13694-devastating-infectious-diseases-smallpox-plague.html"><strong>28 devastating infectious diseases</strong></a></p><p><strong>&mdash;</strong><a href="https://www.livescience.com/56598-deadliest-viruses-on-earth.html"><strong>The 12 deadliest viruses on Earth</strong></a></p><p><strong>&mdash;</strong><a href="https://www.livescience.com/worst-epidemics-and-pandemics-in-history.html"><strong>20 of the worst epidemics and pandemics in history</strong></a></p></div></div><p>Using their model, the authors found SARS-CoV-2 survived on the human skin samples for 9.04 hours, compared with 1.82 hours for the influenza A virus. When these viruses were mixed with mucus, to mimic the release of viral particles in a cough or sneeze, SARS-CoV-2 lasted an even longer time, about 11 hours.</p><p>However, both viruses were inactivated on skin 15 seconds after using hand sanitizer that was 80% ethanol.</p><p>"Appropriate hand hygiene \xe2\x80\xa6 leads to the quick viral inactivation [of SARS-CoV-2] and may reduce the high risk of contact infections," the authors said.</p><p>The authors note that their study did not consider the "infectious dose" of SARS-CoV-2, that is, the quantity of virus particles needed to give someone an infection from contact with contaminated skin, and so future research should also examine this question.</p><p><em>Originally published on Live Science.</em>&nbsp;</p>\n</div>\n<div class="read-more-container"></div>\n<div id="this-will-be-used-for-mpu-2"></div>\n</section>\n<div class="xenforo-comments-see-all">\n<a href="#xenforo-comments-3753">\n<button>\n<i class="icon icon-comment"></i>\n<span class="comments-total">See all comments (3)</span>\n</button>\n</a>\n</div>\n<script>\nwindow._taboola = window._taboola || [];\nvar taboola_lists = [];\nfunction taboola_is_device(device) {\nif ((! device) || device === null || (typeof device) === \'undefined\') return true\nif (device === \'amp\') return false\nif (device === \'desktop\' && window.screen.width >= 700) return true\nif (device === \'mobile\' && window.screen.width < 700) return true\nreturn false\n}\n</script>\n<footer class="van_taboola" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails"></footer>\n<script>\nif (taboola_is_device("desktop")) {\ntaboola_lists.push({\nmode: "thumbnails-f",\ncontainer: "taboola-below-article-thumbnails",\nplacement: "Below Article Thumbnails",\ntarget_type: "mix"\n});\n}\n</script>\n<footer class="van_taboola" id="taboola-mobile-below-article-thumbnails"></footer>\n<script>\nif (taboola_is_device("mobile")) {\ntaboola_lists.push({\nmode: "thumbnails-g",\ncontainer: "taboola-mobile-below-article-thumbnails",\nplacement: "Mobile Below Article Thumbnails",\ntarget_type: "mix"\n});\n}\n</script>\n<footer class="van_taboola" id=""></footer>\n<script>\nif (taboola_is_device("amp")) {\ntaboola_lists.push({\nmode: "thumbnails-a",\ncontainer: "",\nplacement: "below-main-column",\ntarget_type: ""\n});\n}\n</script>\n<script>\nfor(var i = 0; i < taboola_lists.length; i++){\n_taboola.push(taboola_lists[i]);\n}\n</script>\n<div class="xenforo-comment-widget xenforo-comments-3" id="xenforo-comments-3753">\n<input type="checkbox" class="read-more-state" id="xenforo-collaps-trigger-3753">\n<div class="xenforo-comments-header">\n<span class="comments-total">3 Comments</span>\n<a href="https://forums.livescience.com/threads/coronavirus-can-survive-on-skin-for-9-hours.3753/" class="" target="blank">\n<span>Comment from the forums</span>\n<span class="icon icon-arrow-right"></span>\n</a>\n</div>\n<ul class="xenforo-comments-list">\n<li class="xenforo-comment" id="xenforo-comment-14201">\n<div class="avatar" style="background-image: url(\'/media/img/missing-image.svg\')"></div>\n<div class="xenforo-comment-content">\n<header>\n<span class="author-name">Scott Alden</span>\n<span class="post-date">07 October 2020 20:32</span>\n</header>\n<div class="js-read-more" data-rm-words="60">\nThis may seem like a no-brainer, but I\'d like to know the risk of wiping sweat from my brow with my forearm, or touching the hair on my head, etc. I\'m not too excited about having to sanitize those, too. : / <br>\n<br>\nHair can serve as a defense against microbes, but... <br>\n<br>\nWhere\'s my Jetson\'s suit...\n</div>\n<span class="xf-comment-reply">\n<a href="https://forums.livescience.com/threads/coronavirus-can-survive-on-skin-for-9-hours.3753/" target="blank">\n<span>Reply</span>\n<span class="icon icon-arrow-right"></span>\n</a>\n</span>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="xenforo-comment" id="xenforo-comment-14206">\n<div class="avatar" style="background-image: url(\'https://forums.livescience.com/data/avatars/s/4/4966.jpg?1595899244\')"></div>\n<div class="xenforo-comment-content">\n<header>\n<span class="author-name">Chem721</span>\n<span class="post-date">07 October 2020 22:02</span>\n</header>\n<div class="js-read-more" data-rm-words="60">\n<blockquote><div class="author"><span>Scott Alden</span> said:</div>This may seem like a no-brainer</blockquote><br>\nThis not a no-brainer, Scott. <br>\n<br>\nJust ran a search on "sweat inactivation of viruses", and it came back with a link to an article published in Nature from an NIH website*. The original SARS-CoV-1 actually was found in sweat glands in people who were infected and had died from it!<br>\n<br>\nThis likely means the new virus will behave in much the same way. The only reasonable conclusion to draw is that anyone who is infected can shed virions not only by mouth and nose (and possibly feces), but also by skin contact anywhere on their body. Based on this article, one must assume that it can be spread to your arms etc. from other\'s sweat, until proven otherwise.<br>\n<br>\nThe original "no hand-shakes" notion was due to infected people rubbing their noses etc to contaminate their hands, and transmit it that way. Maybe there is more to it than that. We might want to pitch bare-elbow bumps too!<br>\n<br>\nYou have to wonder about all those guys in the NBA crashing into each other, with all that sweat pouring off their skin. Avoid any contact sports for sure. No pick-up BB games for quite a while. Heavy breathing from an infected individual in any sport could also be a potential source, not just coughing and sneezing. Go with golf for the foreseeable future. Fishing is actually a better idea!<br>\n<br>\nSo, if you are going out where a lot of people will be milling around, seems best to wear as much skin coverage as possible, based on this data. This may seem a bit extreme, but an infection from this virus can lead to other extremes as well.<br>\n<br>\n<br>\n<br>\n* "SARS linked to sweat"<br>\n<br>\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7095307/\n</div>\n<span class="xf-comment-reply">\n<a href="https://forums.livescience.com/threads/coronavirus-can-survive-on-skin-for-9-hours.3753/" target="blank">\n<span>Reply</span>\n<span class="icon icon-arrow-right"></span>\n</a>\n</span>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="xenforo-comment" id="xenforo-comment-14253">\n<div class="avatar" style="background-image: url(\'/media/img/missing-image.svg\')"></div>\n<div class="xenforo-comment-content">\n<header>\n<span class="author-name">Valentine Michael Smith</span>\n<span class="post-date">09 October 2020 01:47</span>\n</header>\n<div class="js-read-more" data-rm-words="60">\nJust learn not to fingerfuck yourself all the time. Christ, people.\n</div>\n<span class="xf-comment-reply">\n<a href="https://forums.livescience.com/threads/coronavirus-can-survive-on-skin-for-9-hours.3753/" target="blank">\n<span>Reply</span>\n<span class="icon icon-arrow-right"></span>\n</a>\n</span>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="xenforo-comment xenforo-comments-view-all-button">\n<a class="xenforo-comments-view-all">\n<span>View All 3 Comments</span>\n<span class="icon icon-arrow-right"></span>\n</button>\n</a>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<div class="related-articles-block">\n<div id="expanding-articles"></div> <!-- No tag-links --> </div>\n<footer id="comment-jump">\n</footer>\n</article>\n<aside id="sidebar">\n<section class="box newsletter-signup">\n<div You can unsubscribe at any time and we\'ll never share your details without your permission.</small>\n</footer>\n</div>\n</section>\n<section class="popular-box">\n<div id="popular-box-wrapper" class="style1">\n<div class="most-popular-tab-bar">\n<input type="radio" name="popradio" id="popradio-1" checked>\n<input type="radio" name="popradio" id="popradio-2">\n<div id="popularcontent">\n<div class="flex-row">\n<label class="poplabel" id="poplabel-1" for="popradio-1">\n<span>Most Read</span>\n</label>\n<label class="poplabel" id="poplabel-2" for="popradio-2">\n<span>Most Shared</span>\n</label>\n</div>\n<ol class="popular-list active" id="poplist-1">\n<li class="most-popular-item first-article">\n<div style="width:100%">\n<a href="https://www.livescience.com/trump-covid-enters-crucial-stage.html" aria-label="Trump\'s COVID case could be entering a crucial stage">\n<picture><source type="image/webp" alt="" class=" lazy-image-van optional-image" onerror="if(this.src &amp;&amp; this.src.indexOf(\'missing-image.svg\') !== -1){return true;};this.parentNode.replaceChild(window.missingImage(),this)" sizes="99vw" data-normal="https://vanilla.futurecdn.net/livescience/media/img/missing-image.svg" data-srcset="https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/AnEiwYb3GGEtbhR844B5yH-320-80.jpg.webp 320w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/AnEiwYb3GGEtbhR844B5yH-450-80.jpg.webp 450w, https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/AnEiwYb3GGEtbhR844B5yH-970-80.jpg.webp 970w,
